passages.text: We revise our estimates and target prices for the three Japanese cosmetics companies in our coverage based on 2Q results. Overall, we see headwinds for the sector as a whole, as momentum in Japan is slowing, mainly in sales to inbound tourists, leading us to lower our sales estimates for each company.

Shiseido (Neutral): We fine tune our FY12/25- 12/27 core operating profit estimates by less than \(1\%\) each. Reflecting this, we raise our 12- month target price from \(2,550 to\) 2,700, as we shift our base year forward by six months (to the FY12/26E- FY12/27E average) given the passage of time, and revise our target multiple from 26X to 26.5X. We maintain our Neutral rating, as we expect the core operating profit margin to remain at \(7\%\) or less over the next three years.

Kose (Sell): We lower our FY12/25- 12/27 operating profit estimates by \(1.5\% /2.8\% /2.7\%\) . The company increased its domestic cost- reduction target, but maintained its initial FY12/25 guidance. We lower our 12- month target price from \(5,800 to\) 5,600, as we shift our base year forward by six months (to the FY12/26E- FY12/27E average), given the passage of time, and revise our target multiple from 24X to 23X. We maintain our Sell rating relative to coverage based on our expectation that the operating profit margin will remain below \(7\%\) and ROE will remain low at around \(5\%\) in FY12/25- 12/27.

Pola Orbis Holdings (Neutral): We reduce our FY12/25- 12/27 operating profit estimates by \(0.7\% /2.2\% /2.4\%\) . We adjust our 12- month target price from \(1,300 to\) 1,350, as we shift our base year forward (to the FY12/26E- FY12/27E average, from FY12/26E previously), given the passage of time. We maintain our Neutral rating, as the stock does not appear particularly undervalued or overvalued to us relative to coverage.

Shiseido: (1) Details of the medium- term plan to be announced this year, (2) the degree to which sales growth materializes, (3) whether cost reductions through restructuring proceed as planned, and (4) whether impairment losses are incurred in the Americas segment due to sluggish sales for the Drunk Elephant brand.

Kose: (1) Margins in the Japan business after the new factory starts operation, (2) 2H profit momentum for Tarte, (3) whether the China business can turn profitable, and (4) sales trends for major brands such as Decorte and Albion after price hikes in Japan.

Pola Orbis Holdings: (1) Whether Pola's sales momentum improves, (2) the extent to which new Orbis products contribute, and (3) whether earnings improvement at Jurlique will proceed as the company expects.

China cosmetics market: The market grew \(3\%\) yoy in 2Q (also \(+3\%\) in 1Q). Shiseido's China sales grew in the low- single- digits \((\%)\) yoy in 2Q, while Kose's China sales fell \(4.6\%\) yoy (Exhibit 8). Regarding online sales trends, aggregate cosmetics GMV on Tmall/Taobao \(+\) JD \(^+\) Douyin increased \(14\%\) yoy in July, while Shiseido's and Kose's online sales declined \(7\%\) and \(19\%\) yoy, respectively (see report).

Japan cosmetics market: Domestic cosmetics sales in July (total of department store cosmetics sales and drugstore/cosmetics sales at chain stores) fell \(1.6\%\) yoy, a slight improvement from the \(3.9\%\) yoy decline in June, but still a yoy decline (Exhibit 10). Duty- free sales of consumables, including cosmetics, at department stores have been declining yoy since May, falling \(10\%\) yoy in July (Exhibit 11). July sales in the category were \(39\%\) below the level of July 2019, before the COVID- 19 pandemic.

Valuations: Based on the average of our FY2- FY3 estimates, Shiseido's P/E is 24X and Kose's is 23X, compared with 28X for L'Oreal (Buy, covered by Europe Consumer Goods analyst Olivier Nicolaï) and 31X for Estee Lauder (Neutral, covered by US Consumer Staples analyst Bonnie Herzog; multiple for EL is based on FY2 estimates; Exhibit 16). Average valuations for 12 global cosmetics companies bottomed out in the first half of 2025. While there has been no clear decline in valuations for the three Japanese companies, they are hovering near the bottom of their historical ranges. Given the yoy slowdown in inbound and US sales momentum, and our downward revisions to sales estimates for each company, we see limited upside to expectations for the three Japanese cosmetics companies.

We revise our FY12/25- 12/27 core operating profit estimates for Shiseido by \(- 0.2\% / + 0.7\% / + 0.3\%\) . With this, we raise our 12- month target price from ¥2,550 to ¥2,700, as we shift our base year forward (to the FY12/26E- FY12/27E average, from FY12/26E previously) given the passage of time, and revise our target multiple from 26X (30% discount to the past 10- year average) to 26.5X (28% discount, one standard deviation below the past 10- year average). We maintain our Neutral rating, as we expect the core operating profit margin to remain at 7% or less over the next three years and the three- year sales CAGR to be only 1.1%, which we believe will limit share price upside.

Key points to watch include: (1) details of the medium- term plan to be announced this year, (2) the degree of sales growth that materializes, (3) whether cost reductions via restructuring proceed as planned, and (4) whether the Americas segment incurs impairment losses due to sluggish sales for the Drunk Elephant brand.
Exhibit 19: Shiseido: New and old estimates vs. consensus
Consensus estimates: Sales and net profits from IFIS, core operating profits from Visible Alpha, and dividends from LSEG Data & Analytics
Source: Company data, IFIS, LSEG Data & Analytics, Visible Alpha Consensus Data

Core operating profits (vs. previous estimates): We revise our FY12/25- 12/27 estimates by \(- 0.2\% / + 0.7\% / + 0.3\%\) . While 2Q core operating profits exceeded our estimate, this was mainly due to delays in cost recognition, and top- line challenges remain as sales were below our estimate in 2Q. We therefore make only minor revisions to our core operating profit estimates. By segment, we lower our
estimates for Japan, the Americas, and EMEA based on 2Q results, but we raise our estimates for China/travel retail (TR).

Core OPM: We estimate FY12/25 core operating profit margins of \(13.1\%\) (+3.9 pp yoy) in Japan and \(17.9\%\) (- 1.4 pp yoy) in China/TR. We think yoy changes are likely to be driven by cost reductions (e.g., personnel reductions) in Japan and lower sales in China/TR.

Core operating profits (yoy): Our FY12/25- 12/27 estimates call for yoy growth of \(+10\% / + 46\% / + 11\%\) . In FY12/25, we expect a significant profit increase in Japan and a narrowing of losses in the US, but profit declines in China/TR, Asia Pacific, and EMEA. In FY12/26 and FY12/27, we look for profit growth or a swing to profitability in all segments. In the Americas in FY12/26, we think cost reductions via restructuring will drive a swing to profitability.

FY12/25 guidance: While guidance is unchanged, Shiseido noted a risk of sales falling short of guidance by around \(30bn\) , as sales missed target by \(5bn\) in 1H and the company sees risk of a \(25bn\) shortfall in 2H. The biggest factor in the 2H shortfall risk is inbound sales in Japan, followed by the Americas. Shiseido said it aims to achieve its initial profit guidance through cost management. We believe the company's initial core operating profit guidance was conservative and within reach. One point to note is that Japan core operating profits in 3Q are likely to be weak due to a reversal of temporarily low personnel costs in 3Q12/24.

Medium- term plan: Shiseido plans to announce a medium- term plan starting from FY12/26 by the end of 2025. At the outside directors' meeting on July 8, management discussed the need to achieve ROIC exceeding WACC, stating this would require a double- digit (%) core operating profit margin. As cost reductions are progressing well under the current action plan, we believe the focus of the new medium- term plan will be on expanding core operating profits driven via sales growth.

Valuation: We shift our base year forward to the FY12/26E- FY12/27E average (from FY12/26E previously) given the passage of time. Given also the progress with cost reductions, we revise our target multiple from 26X (30% discount to the past 10- year average) to 26.5X (28% discount, one standard deviation below the past 10- year average). P/E multiples based on our FY12/25 and FY12/26 estimates are 102X and 26X, respectively. The FY12/26E P/E is within the 10- year range for FY2 (from - 1.5 sd to +1.5 sd: i.e., P/E of 22X- 52X), which looks to be at about fair value to us.

Investment Thesis - ShiseidoShiseido is Japan's largest cosmetics company, with FY12/24 sales weightings of \(27\%\) in Japan, \(28\%\) in China, \(6.9\%\) in APAC, \(12\%\) in the Americas, \(15\%\) in Europe, and \(8.2\%\) in Travel Retail (mainly China). China demand's weighting is the highest among the seven HPC companies in our coverage. We highlight falling market shares, lower R&D spending for growth, and demand bipolarization as headwinds. While we expect cost reductions through structural reforms, the five- year average OPM has been highly volatile and low historically or vs. peers/comps. In terms of regional characteristics, we expect some sales/profit growth, mainly overseas other than China, but we do not expect a significant improvement in margins in China due to an increase in the Douyin ratio in e- commerce. We are Neutral- rated because we think the share price looks fairly valued at the current level, with the FY12/26E P/E in the historical 10- year range.
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Research estimates, FactSet, Price as of 26 Aug 2025 close.

We lower our FY12/25- FY12/27 operating profit estimates by \(1.5\% /2.8\% /2.7\%\) , based on 2Q results. Kose maintained its initial operating profit guidance, taking into account domestic cost- reduction benefits. Relative to our previous estimates, we lower our operating profit estimates for Tarte (North America), but raise our estimates for Japan and China, reflecting cost reductions. We lower our 12- month target price to \(\yen 5,600\) from \(\yen 5,800\) , reflecting our new estimates, the roll- forward of our valuation base year due to the passage of time (from FY12/26E to the average of FY12/26E and FY12/27E), and revision of our target multiple (from 24X to 23X (- 1SD to the past 10- year average)). We maintain our Sell rating relative to coverage, as we expect the operating margin to remain below \(7\%\) in FY12/25- FY12/27, and we expect ROE to be low over this period, at around \(5\%\) (our FY12/27E operating margin/ROE are below the average of \(9.8\% /8.4\%\) for the HPC companies in our coverage).

Points to watch going forward are: (1) margins in the Japan business in FY12/26, given expected higher costs related to the new factory starting operations, (2) whether Tarte, for which 1H profits declined yoy, can achieve profit growth in 2H vs. 1H, (3) whether the China business can turn profitable, and (4) trends for key brands such as Decorte and Albion following price hikes in Japan.
Exhibit 23: Kose: Our old/new estimates vs. consensus
Consensus is IFIS for sales, operating profits, and net profits, and LSEG Data & Analytics for DPS
Source: Company data, IFIS, LSEG Data & Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
FY12/25: Kose maintained its full- year operating profit guidance, factoring in the

effects of domestic cost- reduction initiatives \((+x2.4\) bn not included in initial guidance; total reduction of \(\yen 4.8\) bn \((x1.2\) bn achieved in 1H; \(\yen 3.6\) bn planned for 2H)) and better- than- expected results in key Japan businesses, while lowering its operating profit guidance for Tarte by \(- x3.9\) bn. We lower our operating profit estimate by \(- x0.3\) bn overall, cutting our estimate for Tarte, and partially raising our estimates for China and Japan.

China: We expect China sales (excluding TR) to decline \(- 8.4\%\) yoy in FY12/25 \((- x0.4\) bn vs. previous estimate). As 1H sales were flat yoy amid the ongoing closing of offline stores, we raise our offline channel sales estimate to \(- 4.8\%\) yoy \((+x0.8\) bn vs. previous estimate). We expect e- commerce channel sales to decline \(- 9.9\%\) yoy \((- x1.2\) bn vs. previous estimate). We raise our operating profit estimate for China, as the business remained profitable in 1H.

Japan: We expect FY12/25 sales to grow \(+2.6\%\) yoy \((+3.0\%\) for domestic demand, \(- 4.4\%\) for inbound). Factors contributing to yoy profit growth include cost- reduction effects and possible price hikes for existing products.

Tarte: 1Q/2Q12/25 sales were \(- 5.5\% / + 2.5\%\) yoy \((- 8\% / + 11\%\) in USD terms). 1H sales rose \(+0.6\%\) yoy, reflecting improved sales momentum in 2Q, and 2Q operating profits rose \(+14\%\) qoq (both in USD terms). However, the 1H operating margin was \(7.5\%\) , down \(- 6.9\) pp yoy. We think factors weighing on profitability include weaker sales momentum and higher costs related to business expansion on Amazon. Based on the improvement in momentum in 2Q, we expect the 2H operating margin to improve to \(10.9\%\) \((+3.1\) pp yoy), up from 1H.

Valuation: We roll forward our valuation base year from FY12/26E to the average of FY12/26E and FY12/27E, due to the passage of time. Based on share price performance, we lower our target multiple for EPS estimates from 24X to 23X (- 1SD to the past 10- year average). FY12/25E- FY12/26E P/Es are 25X/24X. While the FY12/26E P/E is within the past 10- year range, it is above 23X (- 1SD to the past 10- year average), which we think suggests the stock is somewhat overvalued.

Kose is a major Japanese cosmetics company. In terms of FY12/24 sales breakdown, \(65\%\) came from Japan, \(12\%\) from Asia, and \(20\%\) from North America, and the overseas sales ratio was below the average of \(45\%\) for the seven HPC companies in our coverage. China demand accounted for \(12\%\) of sales in FY12/24. Among our focus points for the Japan HPC sector, we regard regional footprint as a negative for Kose, as sales exposure to China is relatively high. Profitability is also negative, as the average operating margin over the last five years is low, and volatility is high. Our FY12/26E operating margin estimate of \(6.2\%\) is below the \(9.4\%\) average for the seven HPC companies in our coverage, and our FY12/26E operating profit estimate is below IFIS consensus. Based on these factors, we are Sell rated on the stock. Potential share price catalysts include a decline in consensus forecasts due to weak companywide sales growth and a lack of margin improvement in the China business.

We lower our FY12/25- FY12/27 operating profit estimates by \(0.7\% /2.2\% /2.4\%\) , in light of the 2Q results. For FY12/25, we raise our operating profit estimate for Pola by \(+\) 200 mn, but lower it by - 300 mn for Orbis. Reflecting these revisions and the roll- forward of our valuation base year (from FY12/26E to the average of FY12/26E and FY12/27E), given the passage of time, we slightly raise our 12- month target price from ¥1,300 to ¥1,350. We maintain our Neutral rating relative to the sector, as valuations do not look particularly cheap or expensive. Key points to watch going forward include (1) whether Pola's sales momentum improves, (2) the extent to which new Orbis products contribute, and (3) whether earnings improvement at Jurilque will proceed as the company expects.
Exhibit 27: Pola Orbis Holdings: Our new vs. old estimates and consensus
Consensus is IFIS for sales, operating profits, and net profits, and LSEG Data & Analytics for DPS
Source: Company data, IFIS, LSEG Data & Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

FY12/25: We expect operating profits to grow by \(+8.6\%\) yoy, helped by a low prior- year comparison base (FY12/24: \(- 14\%\) yoy). We forecast profits to decline by \(- 8.4\%\) yoy for the Pola brand, which is facing earnings challenges, but profit growth at Orbis and narrower losses at Jurilque. Compared to our previous estimates, we raise our FY12/25 operating profit estimate for Pola by \(+\) 200 mn, but lower it by \(- 300\) mn for Orbis.

Pola brand: We forecast FY12/25 sales/operating profits to decline by \(- 1.7\% / - 8.4\%\) yoy. 1H sales in the domestic consignment sales channel declined by \(- 3.8\%\) yoy. In 2H, while we look for contributions from the renewal of aesthetic treatments from

August and the B.A. series in September, we think it will be difficult for sales to turn up and expect a decline of \(- 2.1\%\) yoy. While 1H operating profits were \(\) 600\(mn above guidance, the company said some expenses were deferred until 2H, and we therefore expect 2H operating profits to decline by - 17% yoy.

Orbis brand: We forecast FY12/25 sales/operating profits to grow by \(+5.8\% / + 8.4\%\) yoy, exceeding guidance. We look for sales growth to accelerate from \(+3.3\%\) yoy in 1H to \(+8.3\%\) yoy in 2H, driven by contributions from a new cleansing oil released in May and a renewed wrinkle- improving and skin- brightening serum product launched in August, as well as a somewhat low prior- year comparison base.

Pola Orbis Holdings is one of Japan's major cosmetics companies, ranking fourth in Japan's skincare market in terms of market share (2023). FY12/24 sales weightings broke down to Pola \(54\%\) , Orbis \(28\%\) , Jurlique \(5.1\%\) , other cosmetics brands under development \(10\%\) , and the real estate business \(1.3\%\) . The domestic business accounts for the majority by far, with the Japan sales weighting at \(86\%\) and the weighting for China at \(5\%\) (as of FY12/24). Pola Orbis Holdings has a low regional sales weighting in China and a low overall overseas sales weighting outside of China, as well as a product mix that could face headwinds as market bipolarization proceeds. That said, our FY12/26E operating margin estimate is close to the average for our seven HPC coverage companies, and valuations do not look compelling to us. We are Neutral rated relative to sector coverage.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Early- Stage Biotech (ES). An investment rating and a target price are not assigned pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when this company neither has a drug, treatment or medical device that has passed a Phase II clinical trial nor a license to distribute a post- Phase II drug, treatment or medical device.
